You can load it in a model structure, and feed the content to another

``` python
loaded = mx.model.load('xxx', 10)

continue_model = mx.model.FeedForward(symbol = loaded.symbol, arg_params = loaded.arg_params, aux_params = loaded.aux_params, other parameters)

continue_model.fit()
```

Hi,

Thanks for your contribution. For the gradient clipping, I think it should compute the L2 norm of all the gradients together right? In your code, you compute norm of each parameter gradient and clip them if its norm is greater than some constant, but the magnitute of different paramter will lead to different magnitute of gradient. In your lua code, you also compute the norm of all gradients together. Another thing is the `max_grad_norm`, could you also expose it as a parameter like what you did in your lua code?

Thank you,
Minjie

Hi,

Thanks for the contribution!

Best,
Minjie
@tqchen , I'm not familiar with R, could you have a look at this?
@thirdwing You can merge in when you feel comfortable

I see.
What's the change to interface?
Could you summarize it and put it somewhere to make it easier for people working with old interface?

@piiswrong The main change is:
- Originally, we use postfix `_data` and `_label` to detect which is data and which is label, and only support one data, one label for input.
- Now there is no special naming convention. The user specify the names of the data in the data iterator, and those names should match the corresponding names (by default `data` and `softmax_label`, to keep maximum backward compatibility) in the symbol. And multiple data/label could be used if the data iterator provides.

I will make a more detailed document soon.
I have also updated the drat repo. Linux and Mac package should be OK.

To install on Mac/Linux:

``` r
install.packages("drat")
drat:::addRepo("dmlc")
install.packages("mxnet")
```
Now all the tests has passed, could this be reviewed and merged?

LGTM in general. One thing, the trick to use first batch to get data shape have a bit detail inside:

Because there is a multi-threaded prefetching. Doing reset next, reset of iterator can cause indeterminism in IO
- Because the thread eagerly produce samples, which will be discarded by reset
- This means when there is PRNG(random crop, resize), the IO is not reproducible.
- Which means slightly different result in different run
- Note we already have not producible result due to indeterminism in cuDNN, but the plain algorithm works 

In the old setting
- During training, we call next, but don't do reset(which is OK as we skip the first batch).
- During prediction, a reset will be called after getting info from first batch, because there is no randomness

So maybe this could be considered, to not expose the shape information, but still do the shape getting trick in model, or provide a helper function in IO to do so, with awareness of train/pred

@tqchen Hmm, I did not notice that. I agree this is a potential problem with `MXDataIter`. I'm not familiar with the underlying data loading and prefetching implementation. But I think there might be a simple way (not making the code too messy) to wire with the Python iterator API so that the first mini-batch could be fetched to check the data shape and batch size without doing an explicit reset.
For `batch_size`, the gradient is already divided by `batch_size` in the updating rule of optimizers. See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L746

Yes, that will need some special treatment in python API, i.e. have a cached instance that will be returned in the call to the next, instead of calling MXIterNext, and support a function like `peek` to get the instance without advancing the iterator(in impl put that into cached inst)

Thanks for the summary!

With regard to shape check, probably implement a peek method?
I guess the peek method from python API might be a good idea, may need to implement peek, next on base-class, and ask the child class to implement a special _next method to get the data.
This is only for FeedForward model. I'm thinking about pushing it into the default setting of optimizers or loss_ops to make it work for every model.

Yes I agree. In the Julia side I exposed more information to an optimizer, including `batch_size`, so rescaling is automatically done for all optimizers (see [here](https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl/blob/master/src/optimizer.jl#L214)). And an optimizer is model-agnostic so should work with any models besides FeedForward. I could back-port that to the Python side if necessary.

For output size, are you talking about single loss operation with multi-dimension output (like vector valued regression or image segmentation), or multiple loss operations (like those deep models where a softmax loss is connected also to lower layer hidden representations)? It seems to me that the situation here is much more complicated to handle _automatically_ for all general cases. Also, though the user might be tweaking the batch size a lot, changing the output dimension might not be a so common thing. I think it is good to have automatically scaling for specific losses like multi-output softmax-loss, or square loss for vector outputs, etc. But still leave the parameter grad_rescale to allow users to do customization.

I agree. Please do a patch if you have time. Otherwise I can do it later.
We can standardize scaling in operators for mxnet provided multi-dimension output loss layers and recommend people do the same for custom layers.
This can help avoid dangerously large gradients when you have a hundred output and use a common learning rate of 0.01.
I think the current code is ready to be merged after we get the peek

./mshadow/mshadow/./base.h:120:14: fatal error: 'cblas.h' file not found
You didn't have blas or didn't set the path to it in config.mk

Actually I would like to propose to simplify of the current data iter base class. I think the idea is to have as less methods as possible so that the user should be able to write a customized data iter very easily, say by just writing a for loop with Python generator api. Common tools like shuffling within a large cached in-memory pre-loaded mini batches could be provided so that the users do not need to implement the same thing over and over again. But this requires more efforts and discussion about the interface.
As long as we have a fixed set of api, it is OK. For example, having a subclass Iter that can take a generator, while have default impl for all the other functions

please aware that if using the BSP model for distributed training, the batch size is multiplied by num_workerss, see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L744

doc https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/doc/developer-guide/multi_node.md#kvstore

Is it viable to unify the handling of mini batch for the distributed training and single-node multi-device training? For example, to let different devices process a whole mini-batch as in distributed training.

the current `batch_size` means the number of examples a process will read each time. it somewhat controls two important hyper-parameters:
- `batch_size_per_device` the number of examples feed into a single device each time. it's limited by the device memory capacity
- `batch_size_per_update` the number of examples used for each weight updating. this is a trade-off between system performance (often in the distributed setting) and convergence speed.

we'd better make the relationship clearer
thanks, I fix it out.
Thanks! @pluskid could you take time to have a look at this?

This looks good to me. I think it is ready to be merged once @vchuravy rebase it to the latest master.

The rational for this modification is that currently Julia is unable to use function with closure capturing for C callbacks. So an opaque pointer object needs to be passed into the backend to hold necessary closure values. This also follows the `updater` API design in the KVStore.

You need those submodules like mshadow, ps-lite and dmlc-core.

It is suggested that you use git to get the code (git clone --recursive
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet), github download does not handle submodules
properly.

Or you can also try to download the submodules yourself. They are located
under github.com/dmlc/

Hi,
If you want the best GPU performance, you can add an operator under src/operator. activation-inl.h would be a good example.
If you just want a quick hack, you can try NumpyOp. Please see example/numpy-ops/numpy_softmax.py

If you managed to create an operator or a working RBF model, you are welcome to contribute to MXNET. Please consider put you work under example and submit a PR.

I have a patch for this but haven't merged it in. I'll paste it here as an example:

```
index ccfb99e..6bb5411 100644
--- a/python/mxnet/optimizer.py
+++ b/python/mxnet/optimizer.py
@@ -66,7 +66,7 @@ class Optimizer(object):
         """Create additional optimizer state such as momentum.
         override in implementations."""

-    def update(self, index, weight, grad, state):
+    def update(self, index, weight, grad, state, lr_mult=1.0):
         """Update the parameters. override in implementations"""

 #convenience wrapper for Optimizer.Register
@@ -120,7 +120,7 @@ class SGD(Optimizer):
         else:
             return zeros(weight.shape, weight.context)

-    def update(self, index, weight, grad, state):
+    def update(self, index, weight, grad, state, lr_mult=1.0):
         """Update the parameters.

         Parameters
@@ -144,6 +144,7 @@ class SGD(Optimizer):
             lr = self.lr_scheduler(self.epoch)
         else:
             lr = self.lr
+        lr *= lr_mult

         grad = grad * self.rescale_grad
         if self.clip_gradient != None:
@@ -191,9 +192,9 @@ def get_updater(optimizer):
          The clossure of the updater
     """
     states = dict()
-    def updater(index, grad, weight):
+    def updater(index, grad, weight, lr_mult=1.0):
         """updater for kvstore"""
         if index not in states:
             states[index] = optimizer.create_state(index, weight)
-        optimizer.update(index, weight, grad, states[index])
+        optimizer.update(index, weight, grad, states[index], lr_mult=1.0)
     return updater
```

- getpad, which was used for reporting number of padded data when data, but as you did in the update, it can readily be incorporated into the databatch

We might need the provide_data and provide_label, either as a list of functions. In that sense, I agree that the peek should be implemented in the subclass, to support provide_data and label for MXDataIter

Yes getpad is not being suggested to be removed, they now exists in the batch object, which is the object returned in each iteration that contains the data, label and other information (including the pad) for that minibatch.
Sounds good to me

MXNet support not only multiple GPU but also multi-machine.

For Feedforward network, there is high-level API which is described here:
https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/model.html#use-multiple-devices
For LSTM, we currently make the example by using low level API. To run on
multi-device, you need to add key value API which is hidden in high level
feed forward model API.
For Speed, you can take this benchmark for reference:
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/distributed-training

if you want use cuda,must use vs2013,the cuda 7.5 not support 2015.

ps or kvstore is a **_system abstraction**_ to implement the parallel learning **_algorithms**_. On single node multi GPU, the algorithm is synchronized SGD. While distributed version support both sync and async algorithms

Yes that is one aspect that we also need to consider a bit. Currently I just replaced all existing metrics with one that naively deal with pred and label list of the same length, by evaluating them one by one and then accumulate. This should be backward compatible with existing behavior, but for long term, we need to think about what would be best interface.
